metadata.description: Time-varying efficiency factors to account for technological improvements over 1965-2024
metadata.methodology: Base efficiency (1965) with annual improvement rates based on historical technology evolution
sources: IEA Energy Efficiency Indicators - Historical efficiency trends
IEA Technology Perspectives - Power plant efficiency evolution
ICCT Vehicle Efficiency Reports - Transport efficiency improvements
Historical data on coal plant heat rates, CCGT efficiency, vehicle fuel economy
metadata.key_insight: Fossil fuel power plants improved ~0.5%/year. Transport efficiency improved slowly (~0.2%/year). Renewables have minimal time variation (already counted in primary data).

notes.oil: 1965: Less efficient engines, lower fuel economy standards. 25% → 30% over 59 years (+0.085%/year)
notes.gas: 1965: Older power plants, less efficient heating. 35% → 45% over 59 years (+0.17%/year)
notes.coal: 1965: Subcritical plants ~25% efficient. 25% → 32% over 59 years (+0.12%/year improvement)
notes.wind: Modern turbines only, no 1965 baseline (negligible wind in 1965)
notes.solar: Modern PV only, no 1965 baseline (negligible solar in 1965)
notes.biomass: Traditional biomass still dominates. Slight improvement: 12% → 15% (+0.05%/year)

annual_improvement_rates.notes: These are ABSOLUTE improvements (e.g., 0.25 → 0.251 in one year for coal = +0.001), NOT relative percentage improvements

calculation_formula.description: Calculate efficiency for any year between 1965 and 2024

coal_improvement.1965: Subcritical pulverized coal plants, ~25-28% efficient (heat rate ~13,500 BTU/kWh)
coal_improvement.2010: Supercritical and ultra-supercritical, ~35-40% efficient (heat rate ~9,500 BTU/kWh)
coal_improvement.2024: Fleet average ~32% (mix of old subcritical and newer supercritical)

gas_improvement.1965: Steam turbines and older heating systems, ~35% weighted average
gas_improvement.1990: Introduction of combined-cycle gas turbines (CCGT) ~45% efficient
gas_improvement.2010: Advanced CCGT ~55-60% efficient, condensing boilers for heating ~90%
gas_improvement.2024: Fleet average ~45% (40% electricity at 55%, 60% heating at 85%)

oil_improvement.1965: Carbureted engines, no emissions controls, ~18-20% efficient vehicles
oil_improvement.2010: Electronic controls, direct injection, hybrid penetration, ~27-30% efficient
oil_improvement.2024: Fleet average ~30% (90% transport, limited EV penetration still)
oil_improvement.improvement_rate: 0.085%/year absolute (slow due to thermodynamic limits of ICE)

nuclear_minimal_improvement.reason: Carnot efficiency limits thermal-to-electric conversion. Reactor temperatures constrained by materials science. 30% (1965) → 33% (2024) improvement primarily from better steam turbines and reduced auxiliary loads.

renewables_no_improvement.reason: Wind and solar data begins ~1990s. Efficiency already captured in primary energy accounting (kWh generated). Hydro is mature technology (1965 dams ~70%, modern dams ~70%). No time-varying adjustment needed.

biomass_slow_improvement.reason: Traditional cookstoves still dominate in developing countries (70% of biomass use). Slight improvement from modern biomass power plants and improved cookstove programs. 12% (1965) → 15% (2024).

implementation_notes.backward_compatibility: When time-varying is disabled, use values from efficiency_factors_corrected.json (2024 baseline)
implementation_notes.future_projections: For years >2024, can extrapolate using same improvement rates, but should cap at theoretical maxima (e.g., coal supercritical limit ~45%, gas CCGT limit ~65%)
implementation_notes.regional_variation: These are global averages. Regional files (efficiency_factors_regional.json) override with location-specific values if needed.
